Submodules¶

LOTlib.BasicPrimitives module¶

LOTlib.DataAndObjects module¶

This class defines different types of data for models. It also provides “Obj”s for bundling together features

For functions, we have a data object consisting of the [output, args]

class LOTlib.DataAndObjects.FunctionData(input, output, **kwargs)[source]¶

This is a nicely wrapped kind of data–if we give it to a FunctionHypothesis, it knows to extract the “input” (NOT the output) and run those on FunctionHypothesis.value(*input) So when you have functional hypotheses, this is a convenient form of data

class LOTlib.DataAndObjects.Obj(**f)[source]¶

Represent bundles of features

class LOTlib.DataAndObjects.UtteranceData(utterance, context, possible_utterances)[source]¶

A wrapper for utterances. An utterance data point is a word, in a context, with some set of possible words we could have said

LOTlib.DataAndObjects.make_all_objects(**f)[source]¶

This takes a list of lists and crosses them into all objects e.g. make_all_objects( size=[1,2,3], color=[‘red’, ‘green’, ‘blue’] )

LOTlib.DataAndObjects.sample_sets_of_objects(N, objs)[source]¶

LOTlib.DefaultGrammars module¶

LOTlib.FiniteBestSet module¶

This is a version of what was called “PriorityQueue.py” in LOTlib.VERSION < 0.3.

NOTE: This is terrible. Let’s re-do this so everything is nice, we can easily add and remove, max/min is more clear, etc.
– have it initialize to extract a certain key from hypotheses, or call a certain function
class LOTlib.FiniteBestSet.FiniteBestSet(N=inf, max=True, key=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

This class stores the top N (possibly infite) hypotheses it observes, keeping only unique ones. It works by storing a priority queue (in the opposite order), and popping off the worst as we need to add more

add(x, p=None, store_iterator=False)[source]¶

Add x with priority p to the set. store_iterator – if we are supposed to store an iterator (rather than elements from it) If p=None, we use self.key to get the value. If x is an iterable, we add everything in it.

get_all(**kwargs)[source]¶

Return all elements (arbitrary order). Does NOT return a copy. This uses kwargs so that we can call one ‘sorted’

merge(y)[source]¶

Copy over everything from y. Here, y may be a list of things to merge (e.g. other FiniteBestSets) This is slightly inefficient becuase we create all new QueueItems, but it’s easiest to deal with min/max

push(x, p=None)[source]¶
class LOTlib.FiniteBestSet.QueueItem(x, p)[source]¶

Bases: object

A wrapper to hold items and scores in the queue–just wraps “cmp” on a priority value

LOTlib.FiniteBestSet.random() → x in the interval [0, 1).¶

LOTlib.GrammarRule module¶

This class is a wrapper for representing “rules” in the grammar.

class LOTlib.GrammarRule.GrammarRule(nt, name, to, rid, p=1.0, resample_p=1.0, bv_type=None, bv_args=None, bv_prefix='y', bv_p=None)[source]¶

LOTlib.Memoization module¶

class LOTlib.Memoization.BoundedDictionary(N=1000)[source]¶

This provides the back end for memoizing, storing the most recently used, and cleaning up by half when we exceed N>2

repr()[source]¶
str()[source]¶
class LOTlib.Memoization.BoundedMemoize(f, N=1000)[source]¶

Bases: LOTlib.Memoization.BoundedDictionary, LOTlib.Memoization.Memoize

class LOTlib.Memoization.Memoize(f)[source]¶

Bases: dict

Provide a memoization class to wrap a function This inherits from dictionary, so if we subclass as something else, we will get other dictionary properties. This acts like a dictionary (inhering from dict) and a function

LOTlib.Miscellaneous module¶

Miscellaneous functions for LOTlib

Steve Piantadosi - Sept 2011

LOTlib.Miscellaneous.None2Empty(x)[source]¶
exception LOTlib.Miscellaneous.RecursionDepthException[source]¶

Bases: exceptions.Exception

LOTlib.Miscellaneous.UniquifyFunction(gen)[source]¶

A decorator to make a function only return unique values

LOTlib.Miscellaneous.Y(f)¶
LOTlib.Miscellaneous.Y_bounded(f)[source]¶

A fancy fixed point iterator that only goes MAX_RECURSION deep, else throwing a a RecusionDepthException

LOTlib.Miscellaneous.Ystar(*l)[source]¶

The Y* combinator for mutually recursive functions. Holy shit.

(define (Y* . l)
((lambda (u) (u u))
(lambda (p) (map (lambda (li) (lambda x (apply (apply li (p p)) x))) l))))

http://okmij.org/ftp/Computation/fixed-point-combinators.html]

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/4899113/fixed-point-combinator-for-mutually-recursive-functions

Here is even/odd:

even,odd = Ystar( lambda e,o: lambda x: (x==0) or o(x-1), lambda e,o: lambda x: (not x==0) and e(x-1) )

Note that we require a lambda e,o on the outside so that these can have names inside.

LOTlib.Miscellaneous.all_binary_vectors(N)[source]¶
LOTlib.Miscellaneous.beta(a)[source]¶

Here a is a vector (of ints or floats) and this computes the Beta normalizing function,

LOTlib.Miscellaneous.display(x)[source]¶
LOTlib.Miscellaneous.display_option_summary(obj)[source]¶

Prints out a friendly format of all options – for headers of output files This takes in an OptionParser object as an argument. As in, (options, args) = parser.parse_args()

LOTlib.Miscellaneous.eighth(x)[source]¶
LOTlib.Miscellaneous.evaluate_expression(e, args=['x'], recurse='L_', addlambda=True)[source]¶

This evaluates an expression. If - e - the expression itself – either a str or something that can be made a str - addlambda - should we include wrapping lambda arguments in args? lambda x: ... - recurse - if addlambda, this is a special primitive name for recursion - args - if addlambda, a list of all arguments to be added

g = evaluate_expression(“x*L(x-1) if x > 1 else 1”) g(12)

LOTlib.Miscellaneous.log1mexp(a)[source]¶

Computes log(1-exp(a)) according to Machler, “Accurately computing ...” Note: a should be a large negative value!

LOTlib.Miscellaneous.lognormalize(v)[source]¶
LOTlib.Miscellaneous.logplusexp(a, b)[source]¶

Two argument version. No cast to numpy, so faster

LOTlib.Miscellaneous.logrange(mn, mx, steps)[source]¶

Logarithmically-spaced steps from mn to mx, with steps number inbetween mn - min value mx - max value steps - number of steps between. When 1, only mx is returned

LOTlib.Miscellaneous.logsumexp(v)[source]¶

LOTlib.Miscellaneous.weave(*iterables)[source]¶

Intersperse several iterables, until all are exhausted. This nicely will weave together multiple chains

LOTlib.Subtrees module¶

Procedures for extracting and manipulating subtrees

LOTlib.Subtrees.count_identical_nonterminals(t, x)[source]¶

How many nonterminals in x are of type t?

Here we add up how many nodes have the same return type OR how many leaves (from partial trees) have the same returntype

LOTlib.Subtrees.count_identical_subtrees(t, x)[source]¶

in x, how many are identical to t?
